title: DANL Project
section: 2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
text:
2.2 MPG and a Type of Cars
The following boxplot shows how the distribution of highway MPG (hwy) varies by a type of cars (class) ğŸš™ ğŸšš ğŸš.

ggplot(data = mpg) +
  geom_boxplot(aes(x = class, y = hwy, fill = class),
               show.legend = F) +
  labs(x = "Class", y = "Highway\nMPG")

title: Welcome To My Blog

This is the first post in a Quarto blog. Welcome!

Since this post doesnâ€™t specify an explicit image, the first image in the post will be used in the listing page of posts.

title: Sophia Rodger
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(skimr)
spotify_all <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/spotify_all.csv')

Rows: 198005 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): playlist_name, artist_name, track_name, album_name
dbl (3): pid, pos, duration_ms

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

# The data.frame `spotify_all` includes information about Spotify users' playlists


# Answer for Q1a
top_songs <- spotify_all %>%
  group_by(artist_name, track_name) %>%
  summarize(popularity = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(popularity)) %>%
  head(10)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'artist_name'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

top_songs

# A tibble: 10 Ã— 3
# Groups:   artist_name [10]
   artist_name      track_name                          popularity
   <chr>            <chr>                                    <int>
 1 Drake            One Dance                                  143
 2 Kendrick Lamar   HUMBLE.                                    142
 3 The Chainsmokers Closer                                     129
 4 DRAM             Broccoli (feat. Lil Yachty)                127
 5 Post Malone      Congratulations                            119
 6 Migos            Bad and Boujee (feat. Lil Uzi Vert)        117
 7 KYLE             iSpy (feat. Lil Yachty)                    115
 8 Lil Uzi Vert     XO TOUR Llif3                              113
 9 AminÃ©            Caroline                                   107
10 Khalid           Location                                   102

# This code finds the ten most popular songs and their artists, with the artists
# being, Drake, Kendrick Lamar, The Chainsmokers, DRAM, Post Malone, Migos, KYLE, 
# Lil Uzi Vert, Amine, Khalid respectively.


top_artists <- spotify_all %>%
  group_by(artist_name) %>%
  summarize(popularity = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(popularity)) %>%
  head(5)
top_artists

# A tibble: 5 Ã— 2
  artist_name    popularity
  <chr>               <int>
1 Drake                2715
2 Kanye West           1065
3 Kendrick Lamar       1035
4 Rihanna               915
5 The Weeknd            913

# This code finds the five most popular artists which are Drake, Kanye West, 
# Kendrick Lamar, Rihanna, and The Weekend.

most_popular_songs <- spotify_all %>%
  filter(artist_name %in% top_artists$artist_name) %>%
  group_by(artist_name, track_name) %>%
  summarize(popularity = n()) %>%
  arrange(artist_name, desc(popularity)) %>%
  group_by(artist_name) %>%
  slice(1)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'artist_name'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

most_popular_songs

# A tibble: 5 Ã— 3
# Groups:   artist_name [5]
  artist_name    track_name  popularity
  <chr>          <chr>            <int>
1 Drake          One Dance          143
2 Kanye West     Gold Digger         83
3 Kendrick Lamar HUMBLE.            142
4 Rihanna        Needed Me           79
5 The Weeknd     Starboy            100

# This finds the most popular song for each of the five most popular artists
# which is One Dance, Gold Digger, HUMBLE., Needed Me, and Starboy respectively.


ggplot(top_songs, aes(x = artist_name, y = popularity, fill = artist_name)) +
  geom_bar(stat = "identity") +
  labs(title = "Popularity of the Ten Most Popular Artists",
       x = "Artist Name", y = "Popularity") +
  theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 45, hjust = 1))



# This code create a ggplot to visualize the relationship between 'pos' and the ten 
# most popular artists, showing that Drake has the highest popularity, while Khalid
# has the lowest popularity. The bar chart shows that all of the artists have a 
# popularity above 100.


# -   `pid`: playlist id
# -   `playlist_name`: name of playlist
# -   `artist`: name of the track's primary artist, which appears only once within a playlist
# -   `n_artist`: number of occurrences of artist within a playlist

# Answer for Q1d

pid_artist_df <- spotify_all %>% 
  group_by(pid, playlist_name, artist_name) %>% 
  summarise(n_artist = n_distinct(artist_name))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'pid', 'playlist_name'. You can override
using the `.groups` argument.

# This creates a data frame with pid-artist level of observations

title: Sophia Rodger
text:
library(tidyverse)
library(skimr)

beer_mkts <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/beer_markets.csv')

Rows: 73115 Columns: 24
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (13): _purchase_desc, brand, container, market, buyertype, income, age, ...
dbl  (5): hh, quantity, dollar_spent, beer_floz, price_per_floz
lgl  (6): promo, childrenUnder6, children6to17, microwave, dishwasher, singl...

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.



top_markets <- beer_mkts %>%
  group_by(brand, market) %>%
  summarize(total_floz = sum(beer_floz)) %>%
  arrange(brand, desc(total_floz)) %>%
  group_by(brand) %>%
  slice(1:5)

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'brand'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

top_markets

# A tibble: 25 Ã— 3
# Groups:   brand [5]
   brand       market      total_floz
   <chr>       <chr>            <dbl>
 1 BUD LIGHT   PHOENIX         271012
 2 BUD LIGHT   TAMPA           171830
 3 BUD LIGHT   MIAMI           152990
 4 BUD LIGHT   ST. LOUIS       140982
 5 BUD LIGHT   CHARLOTTE       136786
 6 BUSCH LIGHT RURAL IOWA      184000
 7 BUSCH LIGHT HOUSTON         154896
 8 BUSCH LIGHT CHICAGO         118916
 9 BUSCH LIGHT TAMPA           110680
10 BUSCH LIGHT MINNEAPOLIS      92992
# â„¹ 15 more rows

# This code finds the top 5 markets in terms of total beer_floz for each beer brand


loyal_consumers <- beer_mkts %>%
  group_by(hh, brand) %>%
  summarize(purchased = n()) %>%
  group_by(brand) %>%
  mutate(total_hh = n(),
         fraction = sum(purchased == 1) / total_hh) %>%
  arrange(desc(fraction))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'hh'. You can override using the `.groups`
argument.

loyal_consumers

# A tibble: 13,202 Ã— 5
# Groups:   brand [5]
        hh brand       purchased total_hh fraction
     <dbl> <chr>           <int>    <int>    <dbl>
 1 2000417 COORS LIGHT         8     3045    0.529
 2 2000711 COORS LIGHT        13     3045    0.529
 3 2001521 COORS LIGHT         3     3045    0.529
 4 2001825 COORS LIGHT         1     3045    0.529
 5 2001871 COORS LIGHT         1     3045    0.529
 6 2001947 COORS LIGHT         5     3045    0.529
 7 2001978 COORS LIGHT         1     3045    0.529
 8 2002617 COORS LIGHT        24     3045    0.529
 9 2002856 COORS LIGHT         2     3045    0.529
10 2003419 COORS LIGHT         2     3045    0.529
# â„¹ 13,192 more rows

# This code calculates the fraction of households purchasing only each beer brand

largest_proportion_brand <- loyal_consumers %>%
  arrange(desc(fraction)) %>%
  slice(1)
largest_proportion_brand

# A tibble: 5 Ã— 5
# Groups:   brand [5]
       hh brand         purchased total_hh fraction
    <dbl> <chr>             <int>    <int>    <dbl>
1 2000235 BUD LIGHT             1     4657    0.499
2 2001531 BUSCH LIGHT           1     1110    0.457
3 2000417 COORS LIGHT           8     3045    0.529
4 2000946 MILLER LITE           1     3195    0.487
5 2001715 NATURAL LIGHT         1     1195    0.403

# This code finds the brand with the largest proportion of loyal consumers


household_stats <- beer_mkts %>%
  group_by(hh) %>%
  summarize(num_transactions = n(),
            proportion_bud_light = mean(brand == "Bud Light"),
            proportion_busch_light = mean(brand == "Busch Light"),
            proportion_coors_light = mean(brand == "Coors Light"),
            proportion_miller_lite = mean(brand == "Miller Lite"),
            proportion_natural_light = mean(brand == "Natural Light"))
household_stats

# A tibble: 10,408 Ã— 7
        hh num_transactions proportion_bud_light proportion_busch_light
     <dbl>            <int>                <dbl>                  <dbl>
 1 2000235                1                    0                      0
 2 2000417                8                    0                      0
 3 2000711               13                    0                      0
 4 2000946                2                    0                      0
 5 2001521               11                    0                      0
 6 2001531                1                    0                      0
 7 2001581                5                    0                      0
 8 2001582               13                    0                      0
 9 2001618                1                    0                      0
10 2001715                3                    0                      0
# â„¹ 10,398 more rows
# â„¹ 3 more variables: proportion_coors_light <dbl>,
#   proportion_miller_lite <dbl>, proportion_natural_light <dbl>

# This code calculates the number of beer transactions and proportion of each 
# beer brand choice for each household

title: Q2a
text:
â€”NFL in 2022â€ author: â€œSophia Rodgerâ€ date: â€œ2023-10-27â€ categories: [news]


Q2a

NFL2022_stuffs <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_stuffs.csv')

Rows: 50147 Columns: 10
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (2): game_id, posteam
dbl (8): play_id, drive, week, qtr, down, half_seconds_remaining, pass, wp

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

 NFL2022_stuffs <- NFL2022_stuffs[complete.cases(NFL2022_stuffs$posteam), ]



Q2b

 filtered_data <- NFL2022_stuffs %>%
  filter(wp > 0.2 & wp < 0.75, down <= 2, half_seconds_remaining > 120)

 summary_pass <- filtered_data %>%
  group_by(posteam) %>%
  summarize(mean_pass = mean(pass, na.rm = TRUE))



Q2c

library(ggplot2)

# Reordering posteam based on mean value of pass
 summary_pass$posteam <- factor(summary_pass$posteam, levels =  summary_pass$posteam[order(summary_pass$mean_pass)])

# Plotting
 ggplot(summary_pass, aes(x = mean_pass, y = posteam)) +
  geom_point() +
  labs(title = "Mean Value of Pass for Each posteam",
       x = "Percentage of pass plays",
       y = "Team with possession") +
  theme_minimal()






Q2d

NFL2022_epa <- read_csv('https://bcdanl.github.io/data/NFL2022_epa.csv')

Rows: 46427 Columns: 7
â”€â”€ Column specification â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€â”€
Delimiter: ","
chr (4): game_id, posteam, receiver, passer
dbl (3): play_id, drive, epa

â„¹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
â„¹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

NFL2022_stuffs_EPA <- NFL2022_stuffs %>%
  left_join(NFL2022_epa %>% select(play_id, passer, receiver, epa), by = "play_id") %>%
  filter(!is.na(passer))

Warning in left_join(., NFL2022_epa %>% select(play_id, passer, receiver, : Detected an unexpected many-to-many relationship between `x` and `y`.
â„¹ Row 1 of `x` matches multiple rows in `y`.
â„¹ Row 24 of `y` matches multiple rows in `x`.
â„¹ If a many-to-many relationship is expected, set `relationship =
  "many-to-many"` to silence this warning.




Q2e

weekly_trend <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>%
  filter(passer %in% c("J.Allen", "P.Mahomes")) %>%
 group_by(week, passer) %>%
  summarize(mean_epa = mean(epa, na.rm = TRUE))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'week'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

# Plotting
ggplot(weekly_trend, aes(x = week, y = mean_epa, color = passer)) +
  geom_line() +
  labs(title = "NFL Weekly Trend of Mean EPA",
       x = "Week",
       y = "Mean EPA") +
 theme_minimal()






Q2f

mean_epa_diff <- weekly_trend %>%
  spread(passer, mean_epa) %>%
  mutate(diff_J_Allen_P_Mahomes = `J.Allen` - `P.Mahomes`)



Q2g

passer_summary <- NFL2022_stuffs_EPA %>%
  group_by(posteam, passer) %>%
  summarize(mean_epa = mean(epa, na.rm = TRUE),
            n_pass = n()) %>%
  filter(n_pass >= quantile(n_pass, 0.75))

`summarise()` has grouped output by 'posteam'. You can override using the
`.groups` argument.

top_10_passers <- passer_summary %>%
  group_by(passer) %>%
  summarize(mean_epa = mean(mean_epa, na.rm = TRUE)) %>%
  top_n(10, wt = mean_epa)

title: Habits
text:
Section 1

some bullet

Quarto
ggplot






ggplot(gapminder) +
  geom_point(aes(x = gdpPercap, y = lifeExp,
                 color = continent), alpha = .25) +
  labs(x = "GDP per capita",
       y = "Life Expectancy",
       color = "Continent") +
  theme_economist()

title: Sophia Rodger
text: Sophia Rodger majors in Business Administration at SUNY Geneseo. When not working on data analytics, Sophia enjoys spending time hanging out with friends and family.
